The 60th sonnet written by Shakespeare has the main topic of time in nature.
Shakespeare is writing about how everything changes over time or comes to an end, but also about how nature is still there even after so much time went by and still continues to exist.
The rhyme form is like every other sonnet from Shakespeare, with 14 lines, there are three cross rhymes and one couplet at the end.
It has an iambic pentameter with alternating rhyme.
In the first lines the speaker compares nature with time to show that nature is timeless, so even though it changes, it will never come to an end (v. 1).
